Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EHR Core: Exploring the Emotional and Motivational Lives of Undergraduate Engineering Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A strong engineering workforce is critical to maintaining a dynamic and innovative United States economy. Engineering programs present considerable challenges, including the need to motivate students and the need for students to have positive attitudes toward learning. Prior research demonstrates that high motivation and positive attitudes towards learning occur when students feel in control of their own learning, place a high value on what they are studying, can regulate their anxiety, and recover from setbacks. While asking students questions about these issues is useful, there is a more direct way to study them - by measuring students' physical responses in real time. A unique element of this study is that in addition to surveys, the investigators will monitor students' body stress responses through sweat and saliva to capture students' anxiety during an exam. The intellectual merit of this ECR project is to broaden understanding of factors related to success using physical signs that a student cannot consciously control and of which they may not even be aware. The broader impacts of this research will come from integrating students' reported perceptions with their unconscious responses to better understand students' emotional and motivational responses to learning, especially those of underrepresented students, who face even greater challenges. This ECR project will support innovative learning environments that promote student success and entrance into the workforce.

More specifically, the intellectual merit of this project is to extend theories of motivation and emotion by integrating physiological responses of students with more traditional measures to better predict student beliefs and behaviors, as well as performance on accepted metrics of success in engineering programs. In addition to surveys, we will use physiological markers based on sweat on the skin (electrodermal activity) and saliva (particularly hormonal markers) to capture students' emotion and anxiety during an authentic exam setting associated with a foundational engineering course. The project will also be integrative in drawing upon theoretical and practical knowledge from engineering education, psychology, physiology, and the learning sciences. It will also broaden understanding of factors related to student emotion, motivation and self-regulation using physical signals that a student cannot self-report as they cannot consciously control and may not even be aware of. The broader impact will come from applying these findings to improving student outcomes, especially those of underrepresented students, who are trying to succeed in an especially challenging environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall, this project aimed to explore the control and value components of Control Value Theory and its connections to achievement emotions (e.g., nervousness), control appraisals (e.g., self-efficacy), physiological arousal markers (e.g., electrodermal activity and salivary cortisol) and performance of engineering (e.g. scores, difficulty, effort) students working on authentic engineering exams. Authenticity of the exams was determined by the alignment of the instructor’s actual course activities and curricular content to the exams that we used for the experiment. We used the context of engineering statics, which is a high stakes gateway course in the discipline of engineering.  

From Fall 2017 to Fall 2019, we collected electrodermal data, salivary markers (cortisol and sAA), exam performance data (scores, difficulty, effort), self-reported data for achievement emotions for a set of conceptual (multiple-choice) and analytical (problem-solving) exam questions. Customized protocols to triangulate these techniques and tools were done and involved a combination of modes and techniques combining qualitative with quantitative data. Throughout the experiments, we found that students antecedent responses (how they anticipated they would do in the exam) influenced their physiology (higher cortisol markers of stress) and how subsequently they performed on the exam. We also found that conceptual problems, as a precautionary measure to help students connect more deeply the learned concepts for analytical questions did not significantly impact performance in students.  

Furthermore, we found that control appraisals (e.g., self-efficacy), both within- and between- subjects positively related to performance after taking into account the physiological responses (electrodermal data). However, the relations between these are convex, suggesting suggests that students’ performance increases with physiological arousal up to a point, after which additional physiological arousal negatively impacted performance.  

The findings have implications both to the practice of STEM higher education. First, the exam design (conceptual and analytical), particularly related to instructors’ decision on real-time interventions to help students cement concepts is important as it may or not prove to be effective. Second, there is a level by which students can experience physiological responses to stressors that are positive to their performance but after a certain threshold, this effect tapers off. Third, the work suggests that cognition and emotion are inextricably linked to the learning and performance process of students and that these involve complex, multiple processes that are intertwined with student well-being. These suggest that the learning environment and corresponding activities does influence student performance. Learning about these details can provide clues in ways to broaden the participation and success of a diverse set of students.  

Furthermore, this work has implications to research. This work introduces novel and ground-breaking methodologies that combine a suite of tools and techniques based on physiology, psychology, education, biology, and other similar disciplines, to holistically understand the student experience to authentic classroom activities and tasks. The findings and resulting provisional patent that was yielded through this work helped establish the baseline by which a new generation of scholars can build upon to understand student motivation and performance.
